title: Alpha and beta particles in decay chain

content.question:
<math alttext="neptunium-237 with atomic number 93 produces thallium-205 with atomic number 81 plus blank alpha plus blank beta with a negative 1 charge"><mstyle><mrow><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>Np</mtext></mrow><mprescripts><mrow><mn>93</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>237</mn></mrow></mprescripts></mmultiscripts><mo>→</mo><mmultiscripts><mrow><mtext>Tl</mtext></mrow><mprescripts><mrow><mn>81</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>205</mn></mrow></mprescripts></mmultiscripts><mo>+</mo><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>α</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><msup><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

In a nuclear decay chain, a neptunium nucleus eventually becomes a thallium nucleus via a series of alpha and beta minus decays. The net reaction is shown. Which of the following is true of the number of alpha and beta particles produced?

choices.label: More alpha particles than beta particles are produced.
More beta particles than alpha particles are produced.
An equal number of alpha and beta particles are produced.
There is no way to determine whether more alpha or beta particles are produced without knowing the individual steps in the process.

content.answer: More alpha particles than beta particles are produced.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
